meta_data.title: Interview Recap // Is Spiritual Disappointment Universal?

transcription_data.text: Welcome to Reconstructed Faith, a podcast where we talk about truth you can build your life on. We hope to dive into the hard conversations of life and faith and seek out reasonable, substantive answers. My name is Colson Lechner, and I'm joined by Chris Legg and Bryn Starnes. This is Reconstructed Faith. Welcome back to Reconstructed Faith. This is your temporary host for today, Bryn Starnes. Wow. I didn't know you were going to do the intro. I figured we'd let Colson do that later. I mean, we can, but we're here. That's right. I am here in studio with Chris Legg. We are going to do a review today of some of the interviews that have posted. I was thinking about it whenever we say review, I kind of wanted to define what we mean because to me, sometimes I, when I hear review, I think of like a movie review. Oh, like an evaluation. We're evaluating or somehow a critic review of, and that's never our intention when we review interviews. Yeah, definitely not. It's more of just, we want to go over either common threads that happened through them or things that we were really impacted by, things like that. I mean, if we have disagreements, but that happens rarely at this point. So there's not going to be a ton, probably with these. Yeah. But I thought I would mention that because sometimes that's how, that's how review sounds to me. And I just wanted to clear up any misconceptions of what we're doing when we review interviews. That's very, very compassionate of you to make sure you clarify that. Like that's not, I hope people would know that's not what we mean, but no, that's a good point. But if they haven't listened to us for a long time, it could sound like we are going back and all right, let's tell, let's rephrase everything that our guests have said. Exactly. Yeah. We don't want to do that for sure. There are times that we may offer other opinions or other options or whatever for sure. But honestly, with our last few guests, I don't know that there's been a lot of need for that because they're, they are all people who to the degree they have faced deconstruction, they have also pretty faithfully been engaged in reconstruction. And so I hope those are still encouraging and for people who are out there and we're intentionally trying to find people who have different types of stories. Part of it's a little bit of a research project for us going, what, what, what does it look like? What's common? And it, I do, I am, I am certainly encouraged by the fact that the need to, or that the experience of doubting, facing challenges, whatever it's, I think, I think it's pretty universal. And I think that shows us at least one part of this conversation is really good. Yeah. We all do this. And I mean, if, if anyone knows someone who is open to talking about their deconstruction story and they're still in the midst of it, they haven't come to any conclusions yet and they're willing to do that and, and understand that we would just be wanting to learn from them, not grill them with questions. Um, yeah, just send us an email and let us know. Cause we would be interested. That's actually another point I think, but on your first comment that you made that is worth noting, part of why we want to be able to talk about the conversations afterwards to debrief them or to review them or whatever is so that we're not sitting in the conversation pestering the person or even arguing with the person, depending on who they are, is that we, we want to be able to let them speak what they, what they want to speak, need to speak. And you know, it's, it feels like either way could be a negative either in the moment, you know, going toe to toe with somebody, but at the same, and it doesn't mean we won't ask hard questions or answer hard questions if they're asked, but at the same time, it, if at least at us and for us at this point, it felt more respectful and we kind of started doing this way back when with David as was, we want to give him the time. And he was also very limited. It was like Christmas Eve or something, it wasn't, but it was somewhere near there. And he, we, we had a very limited window. And I remember Chris and I saying like us talking a lot here is not a good use of the three or four hours that we have. So let's let David talk. We'll ask questions. We'll clarify. We'll push back and we'll accept pushback, but then we'll spend several episodes unpacking kind of the stuff he said. And which is where that started. We mean that to be respectful to anybody, including David, but for any of us. So yeah, anyway. So the three that we're going to attempt to discuss today are the three that, that have dropped since we've kind of done a recap and that's August, Dan Ray, and then Anna Burch. And there's some really cool overlap between these three. So we just kind of want to go through and we may jump around a little bit, but I thought we'd start with August and then we can kind of work our way through just what stood out to us. If that sounds good, Chris. Okay. That sounds great. I'd love it. So there's a couple, there's a lot of things that stood out. I think I was trying to listen from the perspective of, he covered so many things that, that we have touched on before, which I think is always cool. And, and some of our guests listen to our podcasts, but often they haven't followed the whole time. And so it's not, it is really neat to me when someone comes on and starts talking about themes that we discuss all the time and they don't know it because it's reassuring and it's reaffirming of, okay, I think this, that happened with August and Dan, they covered topics and set even said things that we've said before and they weren't aware of it at the time, which is really was encouraging to me. But I think I also try to listen through them and think through what are topics that maybe we haven't touched on as much. So a couple from August that stood out to me was, and we've touched on them some, but I think how to face disappointment when it comes to Christianity is, was a theme that was really impactful of, of how to face when, when you're disappointed by something in life, which we have talked about, but, but with the perspective of when your religious zeal turns into discouragement, skepticism, or disenchantment. So when you are passionate about your faith, you're convinced of your faith. And then one of the quotes that he said was something I may be paraphrasing, but he said something to the effect of is this belief system worth believing, even if it's not applied in Christian communities or the ministry I'm a part of, or even not taking the fruition inside myself that I'm wanting it to. And so that stood out to me as something that, what, okay, what happens when your religious zeal turns into discouragement or skepticism because of, of that? Yeah. So what do you do with that? Because here's my thing. I would say, I guess I don't want to make an assumption, but I will make it anyway. My assumption is we all experience that. Yeah. I don't, I don't think that's, I don't know what the right word is, special as in I've said a lot of times, isolated experience, God, God won't fail you, but He will disappoint you. And so I say that and some people get frustrated because they think I'm saying God has somehow failed when I say disappoint. And I don't mean that disappoints in emotional state. So my friends, my wife, my coworkers, my whatever can disappoint me. That doesn't mean they're wrong. It just means I'm disappointed. And so certainly there's a lot of times that I ask God for things or want something from God or from God's people and they fail to deliver and that I think that's kind of the definition of disappointment. And is He worth following or are they worth being in community with if everybody's going to be big disappointment? So, okay. So where do you go with that? Well, so we may jump around a little bit because of the overlap. So that was a question that even Anna asked that she, that I thought was really insightful of you have to come to a point where part of your deconstruction story needs to be asking yourself if God doesn't answer this the way I want him to, or ask him to, is he so worth trusting? And I do think that's a question we all have to ask ourselves, but I don't think it's put to the test until we have that thing that we can say, yes, God's trustworthy, but until we're having to live that out and actually trust Him in something that is making us angry or sad or whatever it is, I don't think it's put to the test if we actually are trusting Him in that. But I think it's a question, I think that is a key deconstruction question that we all have to ask and is helpful if we ask before the crisis happens, but sometimes we don't. And so, but two parts come to mind when it comes to August quote, I think one we've talked about before, when it comes to deconstructing our opinion and our hope in man and our hope in ourselves. And so I think that's key. But then the question I was going to ask you is what does it look like, like from a pastoral or psychological standpoint, when our faith is tested because we have faith, but the sanctification process in us is taking longer than we had hoped, or we have that thing that we're struggling with and we can't seem to kick it. Can't kick it. Because I think that was some of what he talked about of, I love the Lord, I believe scripture, I'm willing to fight for truth. But sometimes you go through those seasons where it's like, why is this still like, is God real if this thing is still plaguing me? Kind of what do we do with that? Because I think that is another type of deconstruction that we've talked about some, but what if it's my belief in God is real, but it's being tested by the fact that He's not acting in my life as quickly or. That's really intriguing. I have a friend right now who's doing work, really, really his own, I guess, therapeutic and spiritual work right now on, he is attracted to men. And part of his deconstruction question is, if God is real and loves me and doesn't want me to act on this desire, why do I still have this desire? And I feel like, I mean, I just, my intuition, it's my quick response to think that's because, I mean, we're, we are all messed up human beings. Like we all have desires that war against us that would war against what's best. I mean, one of the most consistent things in my life, I mean, I've never thought about it this way, but my introduction to pornography, as I've said before, was around age five, five or six. Well, I'm 51. So that means for at least 46 years, pornography has been a part of my life, sometimes more, sometimes less, but it's never not an issue completely. Like it's never something that I don't have to wrestle with or face or struggle or be tempted by. And in a world that's only become more pornographic as I've gotten older. I mean, there was a day when, you know, it meant sneaking up some kid in the neighborhood, sneaking his dad's Playboy magazine. And now we're all carrying all pornography of all kinds around with us everywhere we go. And it's not like, so it's not like that's faded into the distant past or something. And so, you know, why hasn't God cured me of that, of those sinful desires, especially if he doesn't want me to have them, if he doesn't want me to be tempted by that. And that's, again, I guess that does fall into a question of trust. Like I, I trust that he has sufficient, sufficient reason not to, or not sufficient reason to remove that. And I just, I just think that's the nature of being human is that we're all going to have desires that are not right because we have freedom one and because we're flawed too. But it really, that dull disappointment question, that's really good. And even, you know, Dan talked about even, you know, if at some point in the future he deconstructs his faith, he's saying right here and now on the podcast, it will be any motive thing. It will be because he's disappointed. It'll be because he's, he's annoyed at God about something or is unhappy about how God is doing something. And I, that's an interesting, that'd be worth us spending some more time to unpack. How do we do that? I can only, I feel like I'm only answering for me right now. And I don't know how to answer for other people, how they handle it is, are there universals beyond just well, how do you handle other things when your husband disappoints you? What do you do when they let you down? What do you do when you have a desire for them that they don't respect or fulfill? What do you do? Yeah. And I think so the overlap between August and Anna and maybe Dan too, if I'm remembering correctly, but asking even the question that stood out to me of if I'm disappointed in something that's good, like not just something God doesn't, or I've asked him for, but something that he has called us to such as sanctification or someone else's salvation to pray for those things. So Anna praying for her brother's salvation and saying, even if God doesn't answer this, can I trust him? And that's, that stood out to me as a whole different level of trust and potential for deconstruction because it's something that's good that we're hoping in, um, a certain, that God will sanctify us through a certain struggle or whatever it is that I, that really impacted me. I was, I thought about that for a long time. Maybe for people who are deconstructing and not sure what to do with that, they feel very alone in some of those feelings, but you know, I don't, I don't want, I don't think that people are alone in those feelings. And I actually go so far as to say, I think it is universal. I think there are, there are things very disappointing to me about human existence. There are things very disappointing to me about, uh, the nature, especially the therapist, I mean the nature of trauma and, and why certain traumas are allowed and abuses are allowed. I'm disappointed by all of those. So what do I do with that? And, and part of it is I am counting on someone to make those matter. I'm counting on someone to, to someday assign meaning to those. And I really am. I don't have any hope for anyone to assign meaning to those except God, some type of God, because I am now, I'm completely convinced at this point that humans can't. Right. And so either they have no meaning or God is the only one who can assign meaning. And so, and then we have to wrestle with the fact that he is allowing them, but we'll assign meaning. Yeah. Yeah. Sometimes it's the people on the outside who it's like it's for their sake can't assign meaning, but, um, which is always more powerful psychologically when we're fighting somebody else's battle rather than our own. Yeah. I'm disappointing with God's viewpoint on something. And either I need to give up on God as a person who gets to have an opinion on this or, um, or I'm going to have changed my opinion on it. And so as a bigger, big C church, are we teaching that good things are our hope if they're not God. You never know when a kid is finally going to get something. That's true for all of us. At what point does suddenly something makes sense? I mean, my whole life has been that way where it's like stacking, you know, coins on a scales on a set of scales and you never know how much weight is on the other half of the scales. And when is the coin going to be finally the one that, that tips the scale for someone. And that's not our decision. Yeah. And we're such short, short term. I mean, our attention spans are so yes, too soon. Our attention spans are so short and divided and distracted. And in our, I mentioned this with Anna, but our culture just feeds that so much of instant gratification that that carries over into our prayer life and our wrestling and prayer for others and our patients in that or ourselves, a wrestling and prayer for ourselves. And that was really convicting. I mean, Mason had a similar thing where he had a great aunt, if I'm remembering this correctly, who he'd only met once or twice, but she knew he existed and her family had kind of, they were like Godly people, but that part of his ancestors had just kind of split off and not lived for the Lord. And yet she had been praying for his salvation. And he had grown up in a family that weren't believers in a lot of things. And that great grandma had been praying for them and he meets her like as an adult and she's, I think it's her hundredth birthday party. And she had been, she told him she had been praying for him and he had never known that and had been saved for many years at that point. And it's just crazy. But anyway, that was really convicting to me. Yeah. We don't, we don't have to give up because it's not about us. Yeah. And so we get to, we want it to be about us somehow. And so we think, Oh, I'm failing or God's failing when our art, I feel like that's taking the same attitude as a lot of the narcissistic men client I have when they are like, listen, I was nice to my wife for a week and it's not working. Like, okay, how do you define success? Cause it seems, it seems to me like it's, if you're being nice to your wife, that's working. Yeah. And so, you know, I'm praying to God and I'm asking for him to do this thing and it's not happening. It's not working. Well, unless, unless the main goal is to have an intimate relationship with God and talk to him openly, in which case it's working really well. Yeah. If, if the measure of success of an intimate relationship is behavioral modification on the other person's part, you have a more deeper concern here. Yeah. But I feel like that's part of this is we, we want a solution and we have a solution in mind and we're convinced it's the right solution. Yeah. And we've got the, and, and solution apply that to everything like that, that the timetable and the degree and the process and the person and the, and that's, that's not healthy. The other thing I wanted to highlight that Dan said talking about the cult of the heart that I thought was so insightful talking about, and we've talked about that before, but just the phrase of we create cults of the heart when we create a Christian version of Christianity, that's after ourselves and a version of, well, yes, I want God to do this. And then he has to do this for me for it to be success. And I interact with him expecting all of these things that are built around us and not actually scripture and the character of God. And just him talking about that being what he claims was a cult of his heart. That caused a lot of his deconstruction of having to face that the tyrant that he'd created in his heart, man, which was so good. Yeah. We're not trustworthy slave owners, even of ourselves. I think it's fascinating that once again, although there were some different patterns this time, I hope it's helpful for people who are facing this to recognize, yeah, you're, it should be no surprise when our current faith leaders sometimes fall or when they always disappoint because that's not like that's a surprise. That should not be a surprise to anyone who's read the Bible or who knows humans. And so that I've always thought that's a, that is not a sufficient reason to deconstruct faith is the failure of another human. I think it's understandable, but it's not. It's understandable that you would want to. Yeah. Yeah. Um, that what that reveals is apparently you built, we built something on another person. Yeah. And we are not stable and shifting sands. But when it comes to us, I think we do, it is a convicting to realize whatever, yes, we seek to be like the Lord, to be like him and to be like God and to just be sanctified, but also our actions do affect other people. That's right. And so whether or not they should, it could cause deconstruction and others. If we are living a hypocritical life or somehow, you know, anyway, very good, great content of all three of these. Yes. Thank you to all our guests so far. Yeah. And don't hesitate to, again, to reach out if you're someone who is at any stage in this process and we'd love to evaluate whether or not you'd be a good person to have for us to have a conversation with on the, on the podcast itself. Thank you for joining us for this episode of Reconstructed Faith. If you enjoyed what you heard or were challenged, please leave us a review. It'll help other people find us. If you have questions or a topic you'd like to hear discussed, shoot me an email at info at southspring.org. Reconstructed Faith is a resource of South Spring Baptist Church. Remember, don't give up. Trust God. Search for answers.

This is Reconstructed Faith.
Welcome back to Reconstructed Faith. This is your temporary host for today, Bryn Starnes.

That's right.

of like a movie review.

these.

to go back and reevaluate everything the guy wrote? Sure. Absolutely. But if it's still accurate
and true and right, it's still accurate and true and right. Anyway, I just, I mean, yeah,
New Testament talks about even hypocrites preaching the gospel of preaching for their own
fame instead of actually the gospel, but the gospel is being preached by them. Yep. And truth
is being spread. And like you're saying, we do have to evaluate that it's truth, but right. Yeah,
that's, that's, that's hard. It's humbling is what it is and it should be. And we don't get many,
like you said, we don't get many personal heroes. So let's do both personal heroes, church heroes,
family heroes, because we've heard about that from everybody or faith heroes who stand the test of
time. Yeah. None of them, if we knew them well enough would not one Christ is the only one and
he would still disappoint us. He just would not actually fail. Right. But if, if you say like my,
my dad is my hero, he's awesome. Yes, that's good. And I'm glad your dad is your hero. If you knew
him well enough though, you would also know he can be pretty horrible fallen. Yeah. And, and that's
true of all of us, anyone that we don't know what it is that is so deeply disappointing to us about
them. That just means we don't know them well. Yeah. So that was a quote I loved from Dan. He said,
something to the effect of we have to be bled and drained of the swamp of self-sufficiency.
What a thing for Dan to say. That sounds like David or Dan. David Zollard Dan would say something
that pointed at it. It was such a poetic, it was kind of a grotesque, but pro poetic way of
describing it, but it's the swamp of self-sufficiency is something I think I'm going to say
often. I think I'm posting it on my Facebook right now. Say it again, say it again.
Well, I probably should go back and make sure I'm quoting him correctly before you post it.
We have to be bled and drained of the swamp of self-sufficiency. All that to say,
Anna even talked about that. She talked about just the difficulty of, of us presenting as
a Christian culture that you can somehow arrive. And therefore, if you're at a certain level,
you can't struggle because she talked about when she's had doubts, it's hard to admit to others
that she's having doubts or struggles because we often have that view of, okay, now I've been
Christian long enough or whatever it is and I shouldn't be struggling with this. And,
and it all kind of ties together of, well, but when we're honest, and even she talked about when
I go to my mentors that are my heroes of the faith and they're honest about their life and
their struggles, it gives me freedom and it reaffirms my trust in the Lord because they're
honest that he is still faithful even when they've struggled and they've doubted and how it has an
exponential effect. So I think that's, there's so many things that I've been processing in
Christian community that are contagious in a way of the, I think hospitality is one of those, but
when, because that's one of our pillars, but when it comes to this concept of vulnerability,
I think is also contagious because the more we pretend that we have it together,
the more that those around us feel like they have to do the same. And the more honest we are
about how we've struggled or what's, what has been going on, what it's really like to follow
the Lord, the more that spreads to others that they have the freedom to do that. And that's
another thing that, that really stood out to me. I don't know if there's anything else that stood
out, but moving on to, there's so many good things that these three both have talked about, but one
of the things that Anna talked about at the end, that was another great quote was talking about
how long-term prayer for someone is a marathon. And I, that was, that was just such a good word
picture to me of how often in our laziness or our fatigue, we don't faithfully pray for those around
us that are, that we don't pray for those around us faithfully, but also those who are deconstructing.
Sometimes it takes so long and so many years. And even Dan talked about those that he's working
with in a cult takes seven, what do you say? Seven to eight years, often from the time they
start talking to them, considering the gospel. And Anna was just saying that praying for someone is
a marathon. And we often don't, we're not in it for the long haul because we're weak and we're
lazy and we're not faithful to pray for others because we're like, if God doesn't answer this in
a year, we assume it's not going to happen. Right. Exactly. That's a, you know, we've learned that we,
to quote that one, we, and we've got the, the email that we're going to go over in one of our
upcoming soon that she, both of those, I think you're on both of those that I think it's a,
I remember Craig was a young lady who talked about, I've been praying for my parents, trying
to be an example to them now for a period of time and it's not working. So apparently there's no
point. Right. And so there were several things that we, that we've talked about that are,
that are, that she has, I mean, she's got a lot of courage and the way she's communicating with us,
we really appreciate. I think, I think one of the things that we're seeing is the same thing. I
replied to her as well that, that, that my, my wife, so my grandmother-in-law, the family had
been praying for her for probably 50 or 60 years. I mean, she, and she was very much so rigid in her
thinking. And she saw all these wonderful things going on around her. We actually have the most
adorable picture of her sitting. So Mark, when Mark was seven, no, he was probably like five,
five or six. And he had just learned to read and he loved her. He thought she was awesome and he
wanted to read John three out loud to her. So we've got this picture of he and Ellie sitting next to
her on the, on our front porch. And grandmother is holding, the grandmother is holding a Bible.
Mark's got his Bible open as about a five-year-old sitting next to her. And Ellie has her little kid
Bible open next to her upside down. And Ellie's like four. And so she's just tiny. And they're
reading John out loud to her. And you're like, okay, I would at least fake it at that point. Like,
I would like, and, and she was not, she was like, that was very sweet. I really appreciate it and
all that. She was very, but then, I mean, within weeks before she died, she suddenly just said,
okay, I want to, I want to learn all about this. I want to know all about it. I want to fully
understand it. And I don't know if she knew that her time was running out. Like, I don't know what
happened there, but, and she asked for a pastor to come talk with her who she had never invited
the conversation. And, and in that moment said, you know, I've had all these great examples of this,
you know, for decades and I've realized it's time. It's time for me to, like, we prayed nightly for
her in our marriage for probably 20 years. And so it's just, I would say, yeah, it's, and, and
it's like parenting. You never know when a kid is finally going to get something. That's true for
all of us. At what point does suddenly something makes sense? I mean, my whole life has been that
way where it's like stacking, you know, coins on a scales on a set of scales and you never know how
much weight is on the other half of the scales. And when is the coin going to be finally the one
that, that tips the scale for someone. And that's not our decision. Yeah. And we're
such short, short term. I mean, our attention spans are so yes, too soon.
Our attention spans are so short and divided and distracted. And in our, I mentioned this with Anna,
but our culture just feeds that so much of instant gratification that that carries over
into our prayer life and our wrestling and prayer for others and our patients in that or ourselves,
a wrestling and prayer for ourselves. And that was really convicting. I mean, Mason had a similar
thing where he had a great aunt, if I'm remembering this correctly, who he'd only met once or twice,
but she knew he existed and her family had kind of, they were like Godly people, but that part of
his ancestors had just kind of split off and not lived for the Lord. And yet she had been praying
for his salvation. And he had grown up in a family that weren't believers in a lot of things. And that
great grandma had been praying for them and he meets her like as an adult and she's, I think
it's her hundredth birthday party. And she had been, she told him she had been praying for him
and he had never known that and had been saved for many years at that point. And it's just crazy.
But anyway, that was really convicting to me. Yeah. We don't, we don't have to give up because
it's not about us. Yeah. And so we get to, we want it to be about us somehow. And so we think,
Oh, I'm failing or God's failing when our art, I feel like that's taking the same attitude as a
lot of the narcissistic men client I have when they are like, listen, I was nice to my wife for
a week and it's not working. Like, okay, how do you define success? Cause it seems, it seems to me
like it's, if you're being nice to your wife, that's working. Yeah. And so, you know, I'm praying
to God and I'm asking for him to do this thing and it's not happening. It's not working. Well,
unless, unless the main goal is to have an intimate relationship with God and talk to him
openly, in which case it's working really well. Yeah. If, if the measure of success of an intimate
relationship is behavioral modification on the other person's part, you have a more deeper
concern here. Yeah. But I feel like that's part of this is we, we want a solution and we have a
solution in mind and we're convinced it's the right solution. Yeah. And we've got the, and,
and solution apply that to everything like that, that the timetable and the degree and the process
and the person and the, and that's, that's not healthy. The other thing I wanted to highlight
that Dan said talking about the cult of the heart that I thought was so insightful talking about,
and we've talked about that before, but just the phrase of we create cults of the heart when we
create a Christian version of Christianity, that's after ourselves and a version of, well, yes,
I want God to do this. And then he has to do this for me for it to be success. And I interact with
him expecting all of these things that are built around us and not actually scripture and the
character of God. And just him talking about that being what he claims was a cult of his heart.
That caused a lot of his deconstruction of having to face that the tyrant that he'd created in his
heart, man, which was so good. Yeah. We're not trustworthy slave owners, even of ourselves.
I think it's fascinating that once again, although there were some different patterns this time,
I hope it's helpful for people who are facing this to recognize, yeah, you're,
it should be no surprise when our current faith leaders sometimes fall or when they always
disappoint because that's not like that's a surprise. That should not be a surprise to anyone
who's read the Bible or who knows humans. And so that I've always thought that's a,
that is not a sufficient reason to deconstruct faith is the failure of another human.
I think it's understandable, but it's not.
It's understandable that you would want to. Yeah. Yeah. Um,
that what that reveals is apparently you built, we built something on another person. Yeah.
And we are not stable and shifting sands. But when it comes to us, I think we do,
it is a convicting to realize whatever, yes, we seek to be like the Lord, to be like him and to
be like God and to just be sanctified, but also our actions do affect other people. That's right.
And so whether or not they should, it could cause deconstruction and others. If we are
living a hypocritical life or somehow, you know, anyway, very good, great content of all three of
these. Yes. Thank you to all our guests so far. Yeah. And don't hesitate to, again, to reach out
if you're someone who is at any stage in this process and we'd love to evaluate whether or not
you'd be a good person to have for us to have a conversation with on the, on the podcast itself.
Thank you for joining us for this episode of Reconstructed Faith. If you enjoyed what you
heard or were challenged, please leave us a review. It'll help other people find us.
If you have questions or a topic you'd like to hear discussed, shoot me an email at info at
southspring.org. Reconstructed Faith is a resource of South Spring Baptist Church. Remember,
don't give up. Trust God. Search for answers.
